BALLOT.  Y. Col.   1. Sample of Negro enlisted men 2. Sample of White enlisted men V.I. Cross-Section Identification: E. While the complete sample for S- included a representative cross-section of  Negro and  white troops (AMS-032W) in the U.S. to be used for cross-section comparisons, the Negro sample was augmented to over  to provide additional cases of better educated and of northern Negroes in order to permit comparisons of these subgroups within the Negro sample. -  - AMS-032N

Q.8. Do you think you might want to stay in the Army after the war?  R. Col.   1. Yes, I would want to very much  2. Yes, I might want to, but I'm not sure  3. No, I don't think I would want to  4. Q.33. Do you think there will be another war in the next 25 years or so?  R. Col.   1. Yes  2. No  3. Undecided  4. No Answer  0. No code or no data - Q.34. If you think there will be another war, who do you think will be fighting whom?

Q.33. Do you think there will be another war in the next 25 years or so?  C. Cols. 22-  01. Civil War or race war in U.S.  02. Dark against light races on an International scale  03. Russia with dark allies only (China, Japan, - Africa, India) against any other nation or combination of nations  04. Russia with one or more of axis nations besides - Japan against any other nation or combination of nations  05. Russia with one or more allied nations besides - China against any other nation or combination of nations  06. Russia with no allies against any other nation or combination of nations  07. Communism vs. Capitalism  08. World War III - any line up like World Wars I and II - (same set up as last time, those defeated now fighting the winners)  09. Russia is involved, but everything else is indeterminable  10. Race war but whether U.S. or International not stated  11. Unclassifiable combinations  12. No answer, don't know, inapplicable  00. No code or no data -  - AMS-032N - Q.35. Up to now, has the war made things better or worse for your family and friends back home (such things as jobs, pay, and living conditions)?

Q.40. Do you think that after the war soldiers in your outfit will find it easier or harder to get jobs than they did before the war?  C. Cols. 32-  01. Yes, statement of patriotism, duty, etc. (this is my country, I am an American, protect my country and home)  02. Yes, idealistic aims (we're all fighting for freedom, we got to see that this doesn't happen again)  03. Yes, answer indicating things could be worse and any racialist comment (nobody wants to go back to the feudal age, we know where we stand here - nobody knows what the axis would do)  04. Yes, unclassified answer  05. Yes, no comment  06. No, political or isolationist answer and uninformed about war aims (we wouldn't be in it except for big shots in Washington, D.C., let the - British fight their own war)  07. No, racialist answer (we are 'Jim-crowed, I am a Negro, the axis attacked the white man)  08. No, sore at the draft (I should never have been drafted, I have flat feet)  09. No, unclassified answers  10. No, no comment  11. Undecided, racialist comments  12. Undecided, other comments  13. Undecided, no comment  14. No answer to Q.  00. No code or no data - Q.43. How do you think this war will come out?

If Germany and Japan were to offer to stop fighting now and to give up the countries they have taken over, do you think we should talk peace with them or not?

Q.51. Do you think that after the war you will be treated better or worse by white people than you were before the war?  C. Cols. 44-  01. Better: a militant answer (we will take it, demand it; fight for it)  02. Better: an historical answer (gains were made after last war, present improvements already visible because we are now more intelligent or educated)  03. Better: a virtue will be rewarded answer (it will be because it ought to be, after whites have seen our patriotism, they will change their attitude, we are all fighting together, whites will realize the futulity of their position, we are showing we are loyal, educated, etc.)  04. Better: racial contacts answer and war is bringing us closer (there will be more association and better understanding between whites and Negroes through contacts in Army, etc.)  05. Better: a statement of the specific ways in which it will be better (we'll be allowed to vote, there'll be less discrimination, we will be better educated)  06. Better: a war aims answer (that is what we're fighting this war for, we're all fighting for the same thing, etc.)  07. Better: an inevitability of change answer (wars always change things, changes are always occurring, Negroes can't be kept down forever, promised by God)  08. Better: other answer  09. Better: no answer -  - AMS-032N  11. About the same: an historical answer (nothing changed after the last war, haven't seen any sign of change so far, etc.)  12. About the same: a time perspective answer (only time can change things like this, it will take generations to modify race attitudes, a war won't do it - it'll take education, etc.)  13. About the same: a distrustful cynical answer and militant (whites always make promises when they need us, then take them back after the war)  14. About the same: a resigned accepting answer (whites won't let Negroes rise, we'll never get further than the level whites have set for us, wars won't alter white attitudes, things will always be the same, white people hate Negroes)  15. About the same: other answer  16. About the same: no answer  21. Worse: an historical answer (things are getting worse now, look at how they're treating Negro soldiers)  22. Worse: a resigned defeated answer (whites are never going to treat Negroes fairly, etc)  23. Worse: a prediction of reaction after the war (Negroes will lose the gains they've made southerners will act more harshly in order to stamp out any ideas the Negroes may have gotten in the Army, etc.)  24. Worse: other answer  25. Worse: no answer  31. Undecided: with or without comments  32. No answer to Q.50, with or without comments  00. No code or no data - Q.52.
